column4: Is there a way to test stuff like vga=791 without restarting the comp ?
vga= is special as it is handled in the early kernel process (in 16-bit realmode)
Okay, so is there a way I can test framebuffer modes (I've played with Splashy before, and Links2) and know what resolution I'm seeing for applying it in the vga line ?
you might try fbset, but it's been years since I used it. maybe it's obsolete
oh, cool, I shall look that up then, thanks too
if you're using vesafb, then the mode cannot be changed after kernel boots
fbset will work only for other fbdev-drivers (most of them).

I have an nVIDIA and Trident card both using the nvidia and trident driver, is vesafb separated from it? if not then I guess the mode can be changed after the kernel boots? or fbset would be able to work *shrug*
it would depend on your kernel configuration really. I have no idea. lsmod to see which drivers are used
lsmod | grep 'fb' returns vesafb and fbcon xD; I guess it can't be changed after the kernel boots D:
indeed. fbcon = implements terminal operations using fbdev. so basically the functionality you use to use VTs with fbdevs.
stefg: I see :( oh well, I'm gonna get ready for a few reboots then, but thanks for the help! :D
if you do a lot of fbdev-testing/development, I'd recommend using some virtualization environment. personally I like vmware but there are others.
Ah yes, I could imagine vmware could do stuff like that, but i'm just wanting to have a framebuffer console (with a background if possible) rather than just a plain DOS-like terminal :P
it's not DOS-like :-). DOS consoles are unix-like :-). but yeah, I see what you mean :-)
